title: A
tuple
b

is an ordered, finite list of elements. Tuples are commonly used in programming as a means to work with one single entity collectively instead of individually working with each of the tuple’s elements, and to represent individual rows (ie. “records”) in a relational database.

inline_content.Text: is an ordered, finite list of elements. Tuples are commonly used in programming as a means to work with one single entity collectively instead of individually working with each of the tuple’s elements, and to represent individual rows (ie. “records”) in a relational database.

title: Tuple deconstruction separates a tuple into its parts.

inline_content.Text: Tuple deconstruction separates a tuple into its parts.

title: For example, invoking
GetTallies
c
and assigning the return value to two separate variables deconstructs the tuple into those two variables:

inline_content.Text: and assigning the return value to two separate variables deconstructs the tuple into those two variables:

content_resolved.code: (int tallyOne, int tallyTwo) = GetTallies();
(var s, var c) = GetTallies();

title: You can also use shorter syntax, with
var
c
outside of
c

inline_content.Text: You can also use shorter syntax, with

content_resolved.code: var (s, c) = GetTallies();

title: You can also deconstruct into existing variables:

inline_content.Text: You can also deconstruct into existing variables:

content_resolved.code:
int s, c;
(s, c) = GetTallies();

var person = new Person { FirstName = "John", LastName = "Smith" };
var (localFirstName, localLastName) = person;

var (localFirstName, localLastName) = person;

title: Then you can instantiate a person like so (where we can take a tuple as an argument):

inline_content.Text: Then you can instantiate a person like so (where we can take a tuple as an argument):

content_resolved.code: var person = new Person(("Jane", "Smith"));

title:
var firstName = person.Name.First; // "Jane"
var lastName = person.Name.Last;   // "Smith"

content_resolved.code:
var firstName = person.Name.First; // "Jane"
var lastName = person.Name.Last;   // "Smith"

title: You can also arbitrarily create tuples in code:

inline_content.Text: You can also arbitrarily create tuples in code:

content_resolved.code:
Console.WriteLine(name.Item2);
// Outputs Smith

title: Member names do not exist at runtime. Reflection will consider tuples with the same number and types of members the same even if member names do not match. Converting a tuple to an
object
c
and then to a tuple with the same member types, but different names, will not cause an exception either.

inline_content.Text: Member names do not exist at runtime. Reflection will consider tuples with the same number and types of members the same even if member names do not match. Converting a tuple to an
and then to a tuple with the same member types, but different names, will not cause an exception either.

title: While the ValueTuple class itself does not preserve information for member names the information is available through reflection in a TupleElementNamesAttribute. This attribute is not applied to the tuple itself but to method parameters, return values, properties and fields. This allows tuple item names to be preserved across assemblies i.e. if a method returns (string name, int count) the names name and count will be available to callers of the method in another assembly because the return value will be marked with TupleElementNameAttribute containing the values “name” and “count”.

inline_content.Text: While the ValueTuple class itself does not preserve information for member names the information is available through reflection in a TupleElementNamesAttribute. This attribute is not applied to the tuple itself but to method parameters, return values, properties and fields. This allows tuple item names to be preserved across assemblies i.e. if a method returns (string name, int count) the names name and count will be available to callers of the method in another assembly because the return value will be marked with TupleElementNameAttribute containing the values “name” and “count”.

c

}

title: It may become beneficial to have a collection of tuples in (as an example) a scenario where you’re attempting to find a matching tuple based on conditions to avoid code branching.

inline_content.Text: It may become beneficial to have a collection of tuples in (as an example) a scenario where you’re attempting to find a matching tuple based on conditions to avoid code branching.

title:
if (result == null)
        throw new ArgumentException("combo not found");

content_resolved.code:
if (result == null)
        throw new ArgumentException("combo not found");

return result.Item3;
}

title: With the new tuples can become:

inline_content.Text: With the new tuples can become:

title:
if (result == null)
        throw new ArgumentException("combo not found");

content_resolved.code:
if (result == null)
        throw new ArgumentException("combo not found");

return result.foundValue;
}

title: Though the naming on the example tuple above is pretty generic, the idea of relevant labels allows for a deeper understanding of what is being attempted in the code over referencing “item1”, “item2”, and “item3”.

inline_content.Text: Though the naming on the example tuple above is pretty generic, the idea of relevant labels allows for a deeper understanding of what is being attempted in the code over referencing “item1”, “item2”, and “item3”.
